title: The BCA's new boss is bald, ballsy and from tech
text:
Right man, right time

Federal Treasurer Josh Frydenberg welcomed the "industry experience and insight" Mr Reed would bring while shadow treasurer Jim Chalmers said he "looked forward to working with him on ways to grow the economy and create more jobs and opportunities for more people”.

Outgoing president Mr King said Mr Reed was the "right person" while BCA chief executive Jennifer Westacott said it was the "right time" to have someone with his background, skills, "focus on both big and small business and his passionate belief in the role that business plays in society".

Some BCA members privately admit Mr Reed's progressive approach - which included outspoken advocacy on same-sex marriage - had the potential to spark new tension, after Coalition minister Ben Morton recently urged business to butt out of social debates.

Social activism Ok

His views also put him at odds with former outspoken presidents Tony Shepherd - who recently warned corporate social activism "has got out of hand" - and Graham Bradley, who said the trend "should be resisted".

"I do take on the role as someone who is very passionate about the positive role business plays in our community and our society and the need for business to continue to be present at the table," Mr Reed said at a briefing with selected media on Thursday.

Mr Reed and Ms Westacott will need to walk the line between investor activists and conservative business and political forces, as big companies like BHP come under fire for their membership of the Minerals Council of Australia.

Tim Reed is expected to be a different kettle of fish to outgoing president Grant King (here with Jennifer Westacott). Wolter Peeters

The BCA recently wrote to institutional investors to hit back against claims by climate change activists and clarify that they “support strong action on climate change”.

"I do believe the voice of business needs to predominantly focus on the issues that will drive prosperity for all Australians and drive a competitive nation but I also believe the community expects business to be present in any conversation they feel is relevant to them."

SMEs business too

The pair also face a challenge balancing the interests of their own members, after Medibank dropped their BCA membership this year, citing costs and a lack of focus on health.

However, new members such as Google and Uber have come on board which Mr Reed said indicated the changing nature of the economy.

He said his initial two-year term would include advocating for smaller business, in addition to their traditional base drawn from the CEOs of more than 100 of Australia's biggest corporations.

"We have been thinking about the way in which big and small business work together, what we know is that they prosper together," Mr Reed said.

Advertisement

"I grew up in a family business, I've spent the last 16 years of my career really focused on the needs of small business. I think there are great opportunities for us going forward to strengthen ties between big and small business."

Productivity not fiscal stimulus

Picked from among the BCA's board which includes Qantas CEO Alan Joyce, Coca-Cola Amatil CEO Alison Watkins and Woodside Petroleum CEO Peter Coleman, Mr Reed rejected the need for any wholesale shake-up at the BCA.

He said most of the BCA's policy positions would continue to evolve, including their view the government needed to focus on lifting productivity, regulation and skills ahead of unleashing a major fiscal stimulus package.

"The government needs to be taking a medium term approach to making sure the policy settings are right to lift investment," Mr Reed said.

"The government has fought hard to get a surplus, they went to the election campaigning on the fact they would deliver a surplus," he said.

Insiders said Mr Reed became the obvious choice after standing down at MYOB after 16 years as CEO this year, previously holding senior roles in sales, marketing, product and business development at a range of tech companies.

Mr Frydenberg lauded outgoing president Mr King for his "significant contribution" including his focus on regional communities.

Mr Reed is expected to be formally elected as the 18th BCA president at the BCA's AGM on November 20, which is followed by the group's annual dinner where Mr Morrison is expected to speak.
description: The next president of the Business Council of Australia has a shaved head, doesn't wear ties and will be the first boss of the chief executives' lobby group aged under 50.
